body.p:
Lebanon Tennessee
February 5th 1865
His Excellency
Thomas Bramlett, Governor of Kentucky
Sir

I have been shown to day a petition addressed to you, asking for the pardon of George W Miller now confined in your state prison on a conviction for Larceny. I am well acquainted with nearly all the signers and can assure you that they are amongst the most respectable, worthy and intiligent citizens in and about the city of Nashville.

W. K. Turner was for many years Judge of the Criminal court of that city -- Nathaniel Baxter was for many years Judge of the Circuit Court for the Nashville district -- P. W Maxey was several terms Mayor of the city -- W. Mat. Brown was formerly United States Marshall for the District of Middle Tennessee -- while all the balance are men of good character & high standing in that community
I give full credit to the statements in the petition, and most earnestly join in soliciting the pardon of George W Miller.

The good character & high respectability of the Morther & father & family, appeals strongly in
favour of pardoning a youthful son, whose crime ^arose^ from the intoxicating draft, or by the imposition of an artful & experienced scoundrel. I again entreat your Excellency to give the petition a favourable consideration

With sincere regard
I am your friend & obt. svt.
